title.native: 伝説の勇者ダ・ガーン

description:
Seiji Takasugi obtained a jewel called "Aurin" which is the earth's alter ego and it has elected him to be the commander of eight brave robots. The Brave robots are sleeping in many parts of the world as "Brave Stones". However, they become super robots by fusing with modern people and machines once Seiji awakens them and they soon follow his instructions. Their enemy is Lord Oh-Boss who is an invader who aims at stealing the planet's energy with the aid of his subordinates that Da-Garn and the other brave robots must stop in order to save the world.

(Source: Wikipedia)

tags.name: Super Robot
tags.description: Prominently features large robots often piloted by hot-blooded protagonists.

tags.name: Primarily Child Cast
tags.description: Main cast is mostly composed of characters below a high school age.

tags.name: War
tags.description: Partly or completely set during wartime.

alternative: Yanchar Starlet Banner Greensius Jackkinger Wilder the 14th (ヤンチャラン・スターレット・バンナー・グリンシウス・ジャックギンガー・ワイルダー14世)

node.description:
[Twitter](https://twitter.com/i/user/298477416)

Oobari began his career when he joined the animation studio Ashi Production, working on titles like [Tokusou Kihei Dorvack](https://anilist.co/anime/5143/) and [Sei Juushi Bismarck](https://anilist.co/anime/2361/). Soon after, at the age of 19, he got his first major break when he landed the role of mecha designer on [Dancouga: Super Beast Machine God](https://anilist.co/anime/2255/). Not too long after, at the young age of 21, he was given his first directorial role by directing episodes 5 and 6 of the [Bubblegum Crisis](https://anilist.co/anime/1347/) OVA series. 

Oobari mainly likes to work within the sci-fi mecha and fighting genres. His designs are easily recognizable from the voluptuous female forms and well-toned pretty boys he tends to create to appeal to wide audiences. For references, he likes to use images of professional wrestlers and models. He is friends with fellow former animator and current freelance illustrator [Tsukasa Kotoboki](https://anilist.co/staff/97965/).

He wasn't originally interested in animation but was inspired by [Satoshi Urushihara](https://anilist.co/staff/98177/).

Originating from [Tatsunoko Production](https://anilist.co/studio/103/).
Kunio Okawara was the first in the industry to be specifically credited as a mechanical designer. He is the designer of numerous Real Robots and Super Robots.

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/8tabe5817) | [Wiki (en)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Katsuyoshi_Yatabe) | [Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/谷田部勝義)

Yatabe Katsuyoshi is a Japanese screenwriter and director.     

After graduating he joined the Department of Arts at Nihon Daigaku in 1975. In 1978 he joined Ad Cosmo but felt that as subcontractor there would be no real productions done and thus went on to join Sunrise in 1979. There he learned under [Tomino Yoshiyuki](https://anilist.co/staff/97337) and [Takahashi Ryousuke](https://anilist.co/staff/100957) before becoming freelancer.

[Takuya Suzuki](https://anilist.co/staff/151685/)'s brother.

_Note: Not to be confused with [Tatsuya Suzuki (鈴木辰也)](https://anilist.co/staff/225169/)._

[Takuya Suzuki](https://anilist.co/staff/151685/)'s brother.

_Note: Not to be confused with [Tatsuya Suzuki (鈴木辰也)](https://anilist.co/staff/225169/)._

[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/志茂文彦) | [Wiki (en)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fumihiko_Shimo)

Noted for writing the scripts for Kyoto Animation's anime adaptations of Key visual novels.

Began his career as a production assistant on [Grave of the Fireflies](https://anilist.co/anime/578/), but switched to writing right after.

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/kawasak54965532)

Hiroyuki Kawasaki is a screenwriter and novelist.
Started his career at [Mushi Production](https://anilist.co/studio/68/) in 1963. Later went freelance to further pursue his career as a scriptwriter.

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/8tabe5817) | [Wiki (en)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Katsuyoshi_Yatabe) | [Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/谷田部勝義)

Yatabe Katsuyoshi is a Japanese screenwriter and director.     

After graduating he joined the Department of Arts at Nihon Daigaku in 1975. In 1978 he joined Ad Cosmo but felt that as subcontractor there would be no real productions done and thus went on to join Sunrise in 1979. There he learned under [Tomino Yoshiyuki](https://anilist.co/staff/97337) and [Takahashi Ryousuke](https://anilist.co/staff/100957) before becoming freelancer.

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/8tabe5817) | [Wiki (en)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Katsuyoshi_Yatabe) | [Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/谷田部勝義)

Yatabe Katsuyoshi is a Japanese screenwriter and director.     

After graduating he joined the Department of Arts at Nihon Daigaku in 1975. In 1978 he joined Ad Cosmo but felt that as subcontractor there would be no real productions done and thus went on to join Sunrise in 1979. There he learned under [Tomino Yoshiyuki](https://anilist.co/staff/97337) and [Takahashi Ryousuke](https://anilist.co/staff/100957) before becoming freelancer.

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/fukuda320)

Rose to prominence by directing Shin Seiki GPX Cyber Formula which won the Animage Anime Grand Prix award. 

Fukuda also directed two more Anime Grand Prix award winners - Gundam SEED and Gundam SEED Destiny. With Gundam SEED, Fukuda managed to revive the popularity of Gundam after the commercial failures of Gundam X and Turn A Gundam, which is mostly observed by the selling power of Gundam model kits and toys that Bandai sells.
